name: Kolam
place: Ten Kolam villages (south of Nagpur, India): Dubaguda, Janguguda, Jamini (Duttaguda), Laxmipur, Sonapur, Landgi Pod, Chinchpod, Bhimnala, Raipur (Khadki), Kakban
description: The Kolams (also called the Kolowars) are an ancient tribe mostly spread in south Central India, speaking a Dravidian language, co-located with the Gond and Banjara tribes. The population size is around 400,000. They were foragers until 1940-1950, and practised slash-and-burn cultivation using hoes and digging sticks; at the time of documentation they were agricultural. They have historically (1200 AD) served as priests for another co-located tribe, the Gonds (but are genetically distinct). The astronomy is extensive, if overly generalised: they do not seem to record changes in the sky over the year, and they recall the sky only during the pre-monsoon period when it is well observed. They borrow traditions from the Gonds, who retained more detailed descriptions of some of these common constellations. Besides the 7 lined constellations, three others are unidentified. One is named in two villages, but remains unidentified: the Danedare Pila, a spiral-shaped asterism (either the tail of Scorpius, or a counter-clockwise spiral of stars that also looks like a snake about 10 deg. east of Scorpius). Another constellation in Leo is also named in two villages, having been borrowed from the Gond tribe, but is not well identified by the Kolams: Murda (a dead body). Also, in Taurus is (in five villages) Bhori, a bird (Aldebaran) with two unidentified eggs.

names.english: Golden Cot Pursued by Three Thieves

constellations.certainty: The three thieves are disconnected, as per description and an explicit drawing on slides by the authors (slides not public). This is unlike the variants of other tribes where the thieves are not individually named, so are lined into a procession. There are alternative semantics, since this is a group scene (four objects: a cot and three humans).
constellations.description: A cot (called Mandater) which three unconnected stars (a Kolam, a Gond, and a Pardhan chief, in order starting from the cot) are trying to steal. In only one village, there is an alternative semantic: a container with four edges; in early June, at sunset it is close to zenith and upside down, so pours out the rains (the remaining three stars are on their way to drink the water).

constellations.certainty: The semantic is multidimensional: the plough semantic is recent and clear, but there is an additional (probably older and vague) hunting-related semantic. It also is confused for the line of 3 stars in Cygnus, CON Kolam 018. This version is the one the source appears to prefer.
constellations.description: Tivpate or Tipan (an instrument used to sow seeds) is known in almost all Kolam villages, although in two villages this plough is the sword of Orion, while the belt has the semantics of CON Kolam 018 (a tower of three pots). It is also known as the belt of a hunter, and the region around the Orion Nebula as a sword. (This may be a weak memory of the original Hindu myth which sees the entire Orion as a deer and the three stars of the belt as an arrow.) In one village, the entire Orion is included, not just the belt (but this structure is not identified). In another village, the region around Orion is a farming scene (like that around Sirius, alf CMa) with Medi, Kalave and Tandel or Aidal (a bull).

constellations.certainty: There are alternative semantics, since this is a group scene (three objects: a tree and two humans).
constellations.description: The only southern constellation recognised. Besides the tree itself, alf Cen is Murta (an old lady) and bet Cen is Kadma (a young lady), both there to collect flowers (they are included, unconnected). In one village, these two stars are instead called Oedda (man) and Pilla (woman). In one village, other neighbouring small stars are flowers of Mahua (Irup pokke) --- these are not identified so not included.

constellations.certainty: Slightly uncertain. The source states that Samdur may also be in Centaurus.
constellations.description: Samdur is the Great Square of Pegasus. The name means both the sea (badly pronounced) and an object where all points are equidistant. Five different animals are said to come to drink and feed there: Namli (a peacock), Barre (a buffalo), Pande (a frog), Mekam (a deer), and Gurram (a horse). The source suggests that the stars in the northeast in Pegasus are the deer, Cassiopeia the peacock, Aquila the horse, Cygnus the buffalo, and Pisces the frog.

constellations.certainty: Uncertain in composition. The source says that they probably include some stars above the conventional Scorpius in this constellation, but these are not identified. The lining of the head is not specified, so this line figure makes no head, only links a single star from the IAU Sco head, Î´_Sco, into a simple S-shaped line.
The lining is uncertain. This version is the simplest and most naturalistic for a scorpion: H. A. Rey's, minus two small stars in the tail.
The stars in Cyg are not identified, but the authors (on slides) draw the pots over the Cyg backbone, so the 3 brightest backbone stars are chosen.
constellations.description: A group of three stars one on top of the other, representing three earthen-ware pots put on top of each other, and seen in the northeast after sunset in May-June.

NAME Pleiades.english: One Large and Several Small Birds
Instrument Used to Process the Harvest

* alf CMa.description: A pole to which a bull is tied and moves in a circle on the ground to separate the rice from the husk. The ground is known as Kalave.

* eps CMa.description: A three-legged stool on which one stands to drop the harvest onto the ground, in order to separate husk from crop in the wind.

* alf Tau.description: The bird has two eggs, which are unidentified.
